Here's some good news for Warnock:
Democratic U.S. Sen. Raphael Warnock raised more than $9.8 million in the last three months of 2021 and will end the quarter with roughly $23 million in cash on hand for a reelection battle that could decide control of the U.S. Senate.

Voters have an unfavorable opinion of both Perdue (37 percent favorable, 42 percent unfavorable, and 20 percent haven't heard enough) and Kemp (36 percent favorable, 51 percent unfavorable, and 11 percent haven't heard enough).

Second, the U.S. Senate race:
In a hypothetical matchup in the race for U.S. Senate in Georgia between incumbent Senator Raphael Warnock and Republican Herschel Walker, voters give Walker 49 percent and Warnock 48 percent.

Click below to donate and get involved with Abrams, Warnock and their fellow Georgia Democrats campaigns:
Stacey Abrams for Governor
Raphael Warnock for U.S. Senate
Charlie Bailey for Georgia Lt.
Of course 85% of Republicans believe voting will be easier after the GOP state legislature passed their voter suppression laws while 60% of Independent voters think it will be easy to vote.
In a hypothetical matchup between former Republican Senator David Perdue and Democrat Stacey Abrams, registered voters are evenly split, giving Perdue 48 percent and Abrams 48 percent.
The Democrat disclosed his fundraising figures hours after his chief Republican rival, former football star Herschel Walker, revealed his fundraising numbers.
We will have to keep up the momentum in both these races to fight back against voter suppression and keep the Senate seat Blue and flip the Governorship.

Sen. Raphael Warnock (D. GA) & Stacey Abrams (D. GA)
Here's the big news today out of Georgia courtesy of Qunnipiac University's latest poll.
Warnock's latest fundraising report exceeded his last record-breaking haul, which amassed $9.5 million between July and September.
Voters have a favorable opinion of Walker: 42 percent favorable, 27 percent unfavorable, and 30 percent haven't heard enough.
Inflation is the top issue for Republicans (34%) and Independents (26%) while COVID-19 is the top issue for Democrats (31%).
Voters have a mixed opinion of Warnock: 44 percent favorable, 42 percent unfavorable, and 13 percent haven't heard enough.
Voters have a mixed opinion of Abrams: 44 percent favorable, 45 percent unfavorable, and 10 percent haven't heard enough.
His campaign said he collected contributions from 130,000 donors in his latest report, which spans October to December.
Walker raised $5.4 million from 44,000 donors over the three-month span and has roughly $5 million in the bank.
40% of Black voters think it'll be easier to vote while 73% of white voters think it'll be easier to vote.
And as for Trump's most hated RINO, Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger (R. GA), 36-38.
Democracy and Health are on the ballot this year and we have to be ready to keep Georgia Blue.
Warnock won a Senate special runoff election in 2021 by 2 percentage points.
Election Laws are the second issue for all three groups.
Only 41% of Democrats believe it will be easier to vote.
In 2018, Abrams lost to Kemp by 1.4 percentage points.
Kemp's state approval rating is 42-49.
Warnock's approval rating is 47-40.
Biden's approval rating is 36-59.
